flu-peak-evt

flu-peak-evt Documentation

Influenza extreme-peak modeling using EVT and SIR.

Installation

uv venv
source .venv/bin/activate
uv pip install -e ".[dev]"

Usage

run_experiment examples/sample_influenza.csv --output results/

API Reference

Data loading and synthetic data generation.

Example usage:
>>> import tempfile
>>> from pathlib import Path
>>> df = generate_synthetic_data(n_seasons=1, n_regions=1, seed=42)
>>> len(df) > 0
True
>>> set(df.columns) == {"date", "region", "cases", "tests"}
True
flu_peak.data.generate_synthetic_data(n_seasons: int = 3, n_regions: int = 2, seed: int = 42) → DataFrame[source]

Generate synthetic influenza surveillance data.

Parameters:

  • n_seasons – Number of flu seasons to generate

  • n_regions – Number of regions

  • seed – Random seed for reproducibility

Returns:

date, region, cases, tests

Return type:

DataFrame with columns

flu_peak.data.load_flu_data(csv_path: Path | str) → DataFrame[source]

Load influenza data from CSV.

Parameters:

csv_path – Path to CSV file with columns: date, region, cases, tests

Returns:

DataFrame with validated data

Raises:

ValueError – If required columns are missing or dates are invalid

Season extraction and peak detection.

class flu_peak.preprocess.SeasonConfig(start_month: int = 11, start_day: int = 1, end_month: int = 4, end_day: int = 30)[source]

Configuration for flu season boundaries.

start_month: int = 11
start_day: int = 1
end_month: int = 4
end_day: int = 30
class flu_peak.preprocess.SeasonPeak(season: str, region: str, peak_cases: int, peak_date: date, season_start: date, season_end: date)[source]

Peak information for a flu season.

season: str
region: str
peak_cases: int
peak_date: date
season_start: date
season_end: date
flu_peak.preprocess.extract_season_peaks(df: DataFrame, config: SeasonConfig | None = None) → list[SeasonPeak][source]

Extract one peak per season per region.

Parameters:

  • df – DataFrame with columns: date, region, cases, tests

  • config – Season configuration (default: Nov 1 - Apr 30)

Returns:

List of SeasonPeak objects

flu_peak.preprocess.split_train_test(peaks: list[SeasonPeak], test_seasons: int = 1) → tuple[list[SeasonPeak], list[SeasonPeak]][source]

Split peaks into train and test sets by season.

Parameters:

  • peaks – List of season peaks

  • test_seasons – Number of most recent seasons to hold out

Returns:

Tuple of (train_peaks, test_peaks)

SIR model for influenza forecasting.

class flu_peak.models.sir.SIRModel(beta: float, gamma: float, N: float)[source]

Deterministic SIR epidemic model.

Parameters:

  • beta – Transmission rate

  • gamma – Recovery rate

  • N – Population size

beta: float
gamma: float
N: float
simulate(t: ndarray, I0: float = 1, R0: float = 0) → tuple[ndarray, ndarray, ndarray][source]

Simulate SIR dynamics.

Parameters:

  • t – Time points

  • I0 – Initial infected

  • R0 – Initial recovered

Returns:

Tuple of (S, I, R) trajectories

bootstrap_predict(incidence: ndarray, t: ndarray, n_bootstrap: int = 100, predict_horizon: int = 10, seed: int | None = None) → ndarray

Bootstrap prediction for SIR model.

Parameters:

  • model – Fitted SIR model

  • incidence – Observed incidence

  • t – Time points

  • n_bootstrap – Number of bootstrap samples

  • predict_horizon – Steps ahead to predict

  • seed – Random seed

Returns:

Array of shape (n_bootstrap, predict_horizon) with predictions

flu_peak.models.sir.fit_sir_to_incidence(incidence: ndarray, t: ndarray, N: float) → SIRModel[source]

Fit SIR model to incidence data via least squares.

Parameters:

  • incidence – Observed incidence (infected counts)

  • t – Time points

  • N – Population size

Returns:

Fitted SIRModel

Raises:

ValueError – If optimization fails

flu_peak.models.sir.bootstrap_predict(model: SIRModel, incidence: ndarray, t: ndarray, n_bootstrap: int = 100, predict_horizon: int = 10, seed: int | None = None) → ndarray[source]

Bootstrap prediction for SIR model.

Parameters:

  • model – Fitted SIR model

  • incidence – Observed incidence

  • t – Time points

  • n_bootstrap – Number of bootstrap samples

  • predict_horizon – Steps ahead to predict

  • seed – Random seed

Returns:

Array of shape (n_bootstrap, predict_horizon) with predictions

Extreme Value Theory (EVT) model using Generalized Pareto Distribution.

class flu_peak.models.evt.EVTModel(xi: float, sigma: float, threshold: float)[source]

Generalized Pareto Distribution for extreme peaks.

Parameters:

  • xi – Shape parameter (tail index)

  • sigma – Scale parameter

  • threshold – Threshold for peaks-over-threshold

xi: float
sigma: float
threshold: float
quantile(p: float) → float[source]

Compute quantile of the distribution.

Parameters:

p – Probability level (0 < p < 1)

Returns:

Quantile value

pdf(x: ndarray) → ndarray[source]

Probability density function.

Parameters:

x – Values to evaluate

Returns:

PDF values

sample(n: int, seed: int | None = None) → ndarray[source]

Generate samples from the distribution.

Parameters:

  • n – Number of samples

  • seed – Random seed

Returns:

Array of samples

flu_peak.models.evt.fit_gpd_to_peaks(peaks: ndarray, threshold: float) → EVTModel[source]

Fit GPD to peak values using maximum likelihood.

Parameters:

  • peaks – Peak values

  • threshold – Threshold for exceedances

Returns:

Fitted EVTModel

Raises:

ValueError – If fit fails

flu_peak.models.evt.fit_hierarchical_gpd(peaks_by_region: dict[str, ndarray], threshold_quantile: float = 0.5) → dict[str, EVTModel][source]

Fit GPD with empirical Bayes shrinkage across regions.

Parameters:

  • peaks_by_region – Dictionary mapping region to peak values

  • threshold_quantile – Quantile for threshold selection

Returns:

Dictionary of fitted models per region

Evaluation metrics for predictive distributions.

flu_peak.eval.crps(samples: ndarray, observation: float) → float[source]

Continuous Ranked Probability Score.

Parameters:

  • samples – Predictive samples

  • observation – Observed value

Returns:

CRPS (lower is better)

flu_peak.eval.log_score(samples: ndarray, observation: float, bandwidth: float | None = None) → float[source]

Negative log-likelihood score using kernel density estimation.

Parameters:

  • samples – Predictive samples

  • observation – Observed value

  • bandwidth – KDE bandwidth (auto if None)

Returns:

Log score (higher is better)

flu_peak.eval.coverage(lower: float, upper: float, observation: float) → float[source]

Check if observation falls within prediction interval.

Parameters:

  • lower – Lower bound of interval

  • upper – Upper bound of interval

  • observation – Observed value

Returns:

1.0 if covered, 0.0 otherwise

flu_peak.eval.brier_score(forecast_prob: float, observed: bool) → float[source]

Brier score for binary outcomes.

Parameters:

  • forecast_prob – Forecast probability [0, 1]

  • observed – Observed outcome

Returns:

Brier score (lower is better)

flu_peak.eval.pit_histogram(samples_list: list[ndarray], observations: ndarray, bins: int = 10) → tuple[ndarray, ndarray][source]

Probability Integral Transform histogram for calibration check.

Parameters:

  • samples_list – List of predictive sample arrays (one per observation)

  • observations – Array of observed values

  • bins – Number of histogram bins

Returns:

Tuple of (histogram counts, bin edges)
